revision.text:
{{About|the 2003 film|the 2008 film|The Incredible Hulk (film)}} {{Infobox film | name = Hulk | image = Hulk movie.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Ang Lee]] | producer = {{unbulleted list|[[Avi Arad]]|[[Larry J. Franco]]|[[Gale Anne Hurd]]|[[James Schamus]]}} | screenplay = {{unbulleted list|James Schamus|[[Michael France]]|[[John Turman]]}} | story = James Schamus | based on = {{based on|[[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]]|[[Stan Lee]]|[[Jack Kirby]]}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Eric Bana]]|[[Jennifer Connelly]]|[[Sam Elliott]]|[[Josh Lucas]]|[[Nick Nolte]]}}<!--DO NOT change this. Cast is according to the credit block on the poster.--> | music = [[Danny Elfman]] | cinematography = [[Frederick Elmes]] | editing = [[Tim Squyres]] | studio = {{ubl|[[Marvel Entertainment|Marvel Enterprises]]|[[Valhalla Entertainment|Valhalla Motion Pictures]]|[[Good Machine]]}} | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2003|6|20}} | runtime = 138 minutes<!-- Theatrical runtime: 138:07 --><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/hulk-2003-5|title=''HULK'' (12A)|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=June 11, 2003|accessdate=July 15, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $137 million<ref name=mojo /> | gross = $245.4 million<ref name=mojo /> }} '''''Hulk''''' is a 2003 American [[superhero film]] based on the [[Character (arts)|fictional]] [[Marvel Comics]] [[Hulk (comics)|character of the same name]] directed by [[Ang Lee]] which stars [[Eric Bana]] as the title character, [[Jennifer Connelly]] as [[Betty Ross]], [[Sam Elliott]] as General [[Thaddeus E. "Thunderbolt" Ross]] , [[Josh Lucas]], and [[Nick Nolte]] as Bruce's father. The film explores the origins of Bruce Banner, who after a lab accident involving gamma radiation finds himself able to turn into a huge green-skinned monster whenever he is emotionally provoked or stressed, while he is pursued by the [[United States Armed Forces|United States military]] and comes into a conflict with his biological father, who has his own dark agenda for his son.
Development for the film started as far back as 1990. The film was at one point to be directed by [[Joe Johnston]] and then [[Jonathan Hensleigh]]. More scripts had been written by Hensleigh, [[John Turman]], [[Michael France]], [[Zak Penn]] (who would go on to write ''[[The Incredible Hulk (film)|The Incredible Hulk]]''), [[J. J. Abrams]], [[Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski]], [[Michael Tolkin]], and [[David Hayter]] before Ang Lee and [[James Schamus]]' involvement. ''Hulk'' was shot mostly in [[California]], primarily in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].
''Hulk'' was a commercial success, grossing over $245 million worldwide, higher than its $137 million budget, earning praise for its visual effects, ambition, performances and complexity (especially compared with other superhero films released at that time), while the film's pacing, bleak tone, Hulk’s CGI aspects and lack of more action were subjects of criticism. A reboot, titled ''[[The Incredible Hulk (film)|The Incredible Hulk]]'', was released on June 13, 2008 as the second film of the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]].
==Plot== During the 1960s, [[scientist]] David Banner has the idea to forge [[supersoldier]]s by introducing modified [[DNA]] sequences extracted from various [[animals]] to strengthen the human cellular response, but General [[Thunderbolt Ross|Thaddeus Ross]] denies him permission to use human subjects, considering it dangerous and stupid. Banner subsequently conducts the experiments on himself. After the birth of his son Bruce, he finds that his son may have inherited the effects and seeks a cure, but is stopped in the process by a furious Ross who'd found out about the secret work. Following a traumatic event, Bruce remembers nothing of the incident, and has been raised by the Krenzlers.
Years later, Bruce is a [[geneticist]] working with colleague and girlfriend [[Betty Ross]], within the Berkeley Biotechnology Institute on [[nanobot|nanomed]] research to achieve instantaneous cell repair by using low-level [[gamma radiation]] exposure to turn on the nanomeds once they are introduced into a living organism, planning to use it to cure all from sicknesses such as [[cancer]] and [[Alzheimer's]]. They get harassed by Major [[Glenn Talbot]] who plans to use the work to forge supersoldiers. During routine maintenance of their appropriated [[gamma-ray spectrometer]], a circuit shorts and triggers the experiment's program sequence. Unable to prevent the machine from firing, Bruce throws himself in front of a colleague to shield the man and is exposed to a massive amount of [[gamma radiation]].
Betty visits Bruce in the hospital and remarks that he should be dead, but Bruce feels great. A new [[janitor]] at the lab claims that he is Bruce's biological father, whom Bruce forgot. Bruce presumes the janitor was lying until he finds it was truth when he checks his own genes. When under extreme stress, Bruce transforms into the Hulk, a huge, humanoid, green-skinned monstrous being who destroys the laboratory, though Bruce forgets soon after. General Ross suspects Bruce of collaborating with David Banner but deduces Bruce has [[repressed memories]] after questioning. He orders Bruce to be put under house arrest.
Through a phone call with his father, Bruce learns that the radiation unleashed something that was already in his DNA, and that David Banner plans to have Betty killed by his [[dogs]], which now have similar powers to the Hulk thanks to David mutating them with gamma radiation. Bruce is then attacked by Talbot who accused him of going behind the back to cut him from the work, leading to a second transforming into the Hulk. The Hulk seriously injures Talbot before leaping to save Betty. After being wounded in a lengthy struggle, he kills David's dogs and changes back into Bruce before being captured by the military the next morning.
Bruce is kept under observation at a secret desert base, while Talbot intends to weaponize the Hulk's powers. David tries to recreate Bruce's failed experiment, but instead of turning into another Hulk he finds himself able to [[Absorbing Man|absorb any material he touches]] or energy to which he is exposed. He hands himself over to the military after lying to Betty and telling that he had accidentally murdered his wife in front of the child Bruce due to fury done by Ross's interference.
Bruce has a nightmare about the event, he realises his father thought he was a monster and tried to kill him while his mother [[Self sacrifice|protected him]]. This leads to a more powerful transformation into the Hulk. While attempting to gain a sample of the monster, Talbot is killed by a [[grenade-launcher]] he uses. The Hulk escapes Desert Base and rampages across the desert to [[San Francisco]], battling Army forces sent after him. Betty calms Bruce into his human form.
David tries to taunt his son into transforming into the Hulk, but fails. He then decides to "go first" and bites an electrical cable, absorbing all the electricity in San Francisco. The electricity hits Bruce, triggering his own transformation. A brutal fight ensues between David and the Hulk, with David absorbing the Hulk's energy. It proves too much for David to handle, but when he himself transforms into a massive creature, he is killed by an Army missile. One year later, Bruce is presumed dead, while General Ross mentions apparent Hulk sightings and Betty admits her love for Bruce. In a [[South American]] [[jungle]], Bruce has become a doctor and is approached by rebel militants who want to take medical supplies from the poor. Bruce faces the militants' leader, warning him that, "You wouldn't like me when I'm angry". His eye turns green and the roar of the Hulk is heard from the distance.
==Cast== *[[Eric Bana]] as [[Hulk (comics)|Bruce Banner / Hulk]] (known legally as Bruce Krenzler throughout the movie): a gamma-radiation research scientist who was exposed to a large amount of gamma radiations in an accident in his labs and after the incident. Bana was cast in October 2001, signing for an additional two sequels.<ref name=Rider/> Ang Lee felt obliged to cast Bana upon seeing ''[[Chopper (film)|Chopper]]'', and first approached the actor in July 2001.<ref name=Chopper>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url = http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2269|title = Countdown to ''Hulk'': Ang Lee's new green destiny|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-19|accessdate = 2008-06-17}}</ref> The role was heavily pursued by other actors. Bana was also in heavy contention for ''[[Ghost Rider (2007 film)|Ghost Rider]]'', but lost out to [[Nicolas Cage]].<ref name=Rider/> Bana explained, "I was obsessed with [[The Incredible Hulk (1978 TV series)|the TV show]]. I was never a huge comic book reader when I was a kid, but was completely obsessed with the television show."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/art-main.html?2001-12/27/12.00.film |title=Bana was TV ''Hulk'' Fan |publisher=[[Sci Fi Wire]] |date=2001-12-27 |accessdate=2010-04-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401080622/http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/art-main.html?2001-12%2F27%2F12.00.film |archivedate=2008-04-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It was widely reported [[Billy Crudup]] turned down the role. [[Johnny Depp]] and [[Steve Buscemi]] were reported to be under consideration for the lead.<ref name=Hughes/> [[Edward Norton]], who went on to play the part in ''[[The Incredible Hulk (film)|The Incredible Hulk]]'', expressed interest in the role. Norton eventually turned down the part as he was disappointed with the script.<ref>{{cite news|author = Edward Douglas|title = Zak Penn on Norton as ''Hulk''!|publisher = [[Superhero Hype!]]|date = 2007-04-16|url = http://www.superherohype.com/news/topnews.php?id=5506|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref><ref name=mull>{{cite news|title = Edward Norton talks Incredible Hulk|work= [[Total Film]]|date = 2008-03-07|url = http://www.totalfilm.com/features/edward-norton-talks-incredible-hulk| accessdate=2010-04-27}}</ref> :*[[Mike Erwin]] as sixteen-year-old Bruce Banner :*Damon James as nine-year-old Bruce Banner :*Bailey James as five-year-old Bruce Banner :*Michael Kronenberg as four-year-old Bruce Banner :*David Kronenberg as two-year-old Bruce Banner
*[[Jennifer Connelly]] as [[Betty Ross]]: Bruce's ex-girlfriend/co-researcher, as well as estranged daughter of General Ross. Betty is possibly the only way for the Hulk to lead back into his transformation of Bruce. Connelly was attracted to the role by way of director Ang Lee. "He's not talking about a guy running around in green tights and a glossy fun-filled movie for kids. He's talking along the lines of tragedy and psychodrama. I find it interesting, the green monster of rage and greed, jealousy and fear in all of us."<ref>{{cite news|title=Connelly Embraces ''The Hulk'' |publisher=[[Sci Fi Wire]] |date=2001-12-10 |url=http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/art-main.html?2001-12/10/13.00.film |accessdate=2010-04-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214063756/http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/art-main.html?2001-12%2F10%2F13.00.film |archivedate=2008-02-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> :*[[Rhiannon Leigh Wryn]] as young Betty Ross
*[[Sam Elliott]] as [[Thunderbolt Ross|General Thunderbolt Ross]]: A four-star general and estranged father of Betty. Ross was responsible for prohibiting David Banner from his lab work after learning of his dangerous experiments. Elliott felt his performance was similar to his portrayal of [[Basil L. Plumley]] in ''[[We Were Soldiers]]''.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|title = Elliott Talks ''Hulk''|publisher = Comics2Film|date = 2002-02-28|url = http://www.mania.com/elliott-talks-bihulkib_article_87814.html| accessdate = 2010-04-27}}</ref> Elliott accepted the role without reading the script, being simply too excited to work with Ang Lee. In addition Elliot also researched Hulk comic books for the part.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url = http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2232|title = Countdown to ''Hulk'': Sam Elliott: Hulkbuster|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-11|accessdate = 2008-06-17}}</ref> :*Todd Tesen as Young Thaddeus Ross
*[[Josh Lucas]] as [[Glenn Talbot|Major Glenn Talbot]]: A ruthless former soldier who offers Banner and Betty Ross an opportunity to work for him in an attempt to start an experiment on self-healing soldiers. *[[Nick Nolte]] as [[Brian Banner|Dr. David Banner / The Father]]: The mentally unstable biological father of Bruce Banner who was also a genetics research scientist and had been locked away for 30 years after causing an explosion in the gamma reactor and accidentally killing his wife, Edith. After exposing himself to gamma radiation, he gains the ability to combine with the essence of all physical objects, reminiscent of the comic book character [[Absorbing Man]], one of the characters that first appeared in the early scripts of the film. He also, at one point, becomes a towering creature composed of electricity, reminiscent of [[Zzzax]], one of the Hulk's enemies in the comic series.<ref name="Hater">{{cite news|author = KJB|title = David Hater Talks ''Hulk''|publisher = [[IGN]]|url = http://movies.ign.com/articles/036/036564p1.html|accessdate=2008-06-11}}</ref> Nolte agreed to participate in the film when Ang Lee described the project as a "Greek tragedy."<ref>{{cite web|last=Bonin|first=Liane|title=''Hulk'' 's Nick Nolte on rage, science, and Shakespeare|date=19 June 2003|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2003/06/19/hulks-nick-nolte-rage-science-and-shakespeare|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Alana|title=Nick Nolte: Hulk|date=15 July 2003|publisher=[[BBC]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2003/06/30/nick_nolte_hulk_interview.shtml|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref> :*[[Paul Kersey (actor)|Paul Kersey]] as Young David Banner
*[[Cara Buono]] as Edith Banner: Bruce's biological mother whom he cannot remember. She is heard, but mostly appears in Bruce's nightmares. *[[Celia Weston]] as Mrs. Krenzler: Bruce's [[adoption|adoptive]] mother who cared for him after the death of Edith and David's incarceration. *[[Kevin Rankin (actor)|Kevin Rankin]] as Harper: Bruce's colleague whom he saved from the gamma radiations. *[[Jesse Corti]] as Colonel
Hulk co-creator/[[executive producer]] [[Stan Lee]] and former ''Hulk'' actor [[Lou Ferrigno]] made [[cameo appearance]]s in the film as [[security guard]]s. [[Johnny Kastl]] and [[Daniel Dae Kim]] have small roles as soldiers.
==Development==
===Jonathan Hensleigh=== Producers [[Avi Arad]] and [[Gale Anne Hurd]] began the development for ''Hulk'' in 1990,<ref name=Hurd>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url =http://www.mania.com/bcomiccon-ihulk-hulk-hulkib_article_88790.html|title = Comic-Con: ''Hulk'', ''Hulk'', ''Hulk''!|publisher = Comics2Film|date = 2002-08-06|accessdate = 2010-04-27}}</ref> the same year the final [[Death of the Incredible Hulk|TV movie based on the 1970s TV series]] aired. They set the property up at [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] in 1992.<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR101955|title = Marvel Characters holding attraction for filmmakers|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1992-12-12|accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref> [[Michael France]] and Stan Lee were invited into Universal's offices in 1994, with France writing the script. Universal's concept was to have the Hulk battle [[terrorists]], an idea France disliked. [[John Turman]], a Hulk comic book fan, was brought to write the script in 1995, getting approval from Lee. Turman wrote ten drafts and was heavily influenced by the ''[[Tales to Astonish#The Hulk and the Sub-Mariner|Tales to Astonish]]'' issues, which pitted the Hulk against General Ross and the military,<ref name=dream/> the [[Leader (comics)|Leader]], [[Rick Jones (comics)|Rick Jones]], the atomic explosion origin from the comics,<ref name=make/> and [[Brian Banner]] as the explanation for Bruce's inner anger. Universal had mixed feelings over Turman's script, but nonetheless future screenwriters would use many elements.<ref name=dream>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url =http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2191|title = Countdown to ''Hulk'': Screenwriter John Turman talks about a fan's dream job|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-05-30|accessdate = 2008-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url =http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2196|title = Countdown to ''Hulk'': Screenwriter John Turman talks about ''Hulk'' and other heroes|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-01|accessdate = 2008-06-14}}</ref>
Hurd brought her husband [[Jonathan Hensleigh]] as co-producer the following year and [[Industrial Light & Magic]] was hired to use [[computer-generated imagery]] to create the Hulk. Universal was courting France once more to write the script,<ref name=Hughes>{{cite book|author = David Hughes|title = Comic Book Movies|publisher = [[Virgin Books]]|year = 2003|location = [[London]]|pages = 261–269|isbn = 0-7535-0767-6}}</ref> but changed their minds when [[Joe Johnston]] became the director in April 1997.<ref>{{cite news|author = Michael Fleming|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117434784|title = A Mania For Marvel|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1997-04-14|accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref> The studio wanted Hensleigh to rewrite the script due to his successful results on Johnston's ''[[Jumanji (film)|Jumanji]]''. France was fired before he wrote a single page, but received a buy-off from Universal.<ref name=Hughes/> Johnston dropped out of directing in July 1997 in favor of ''[[October Sky]]'', and Hensleigh convinced Universal to make the ''Hulk'' his directing debut. Turman was brought back a second time to write two more drafts. [[Zak Penn]] then rewrote it.<ref name=Hughes/><ref>{{cite news|author = Michael Fleming|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1116677365|title = ''Hoop'' duo go hip-hop|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1997-07-08|accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref> His script featured a fight between the Hulk and a school of sharks,<ref name=make>{{cite news|author = [[Harry Knowles]]|title = Make John Turman or Zack Penn's ''Hulk'' Drafts, not Hensleigh's!!!!!!|publisher = [[Ain't It Cool News]]|date = 1997-11-10|url = http://www.aintitcool.com/node/248|accessdate=2008-03-07}}</ref> as well as two scenes he eventually used for the 2008 film; Banner realizing he is unable to have sex, and triggering a transformation by falling out of a helicopter.<ref>{{cite news|author=Anne Thompson |url=http://weblogs.variety.com/thompsononhollywood/2008/06/incredible-hu-1.html |title=Incredible Hulk: Setting the Record Straight |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=2008-06-13 |accessdate=2008-10-24 |authorlink=Anne Thompson (film critic) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617113606/http://weblogs.variety.com/thompsononhollywood/2008/06/incredible-hu-1.html |archivedate=June 17, 2008 }}</ref> Hensleigh rewrote from scratch, coming up with a brand new storyline<ref name=Hughes/> featuring Bruce Banner, who prior to the accident which will turn him into The Hulk, experimenting with gamma-irradiated insect DNA on three convicts. This transforms the convicts into "insect men" that cause havoc.<ref name=Hughes/><ref name=bulk/> [[File:Hulkinsect.jpg|thumb|Concept art for Jonathan Hensleigh's script]] Filming was set to start in December 1997 in [[Arizona]] for a summer 1999 release date, but filming was pushed back for four months.<ref name=bulk>{{cite news|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1116675959|title = U bulks up ''Hulk''|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1997-08-11|accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref><ref name=Karon/> Hensleigh subsequently rewrote the script with [[J. J. Abrams]]. [[Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski]] were also brought on board to rewrite with Hensleigh still attached as director.<ref name=Hughes/> In October 1997, ''Hulk'' had entered [[pre-production]] with the creation of [[prosthetic makeup]] and [[computer animation]] already under way. [[Gregory Sporleder]] was cast as "Novak", Banner's archenemy while [[Lynn "Red" Williams]] was cast as a convict who transforms into a combination of human, ant and beetle.<ref name=Karon>{{cite news|author = Paul Karon|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1116674626|title = U adds duo to ''Hulk'' cast|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1997-10-31|accessdate = 2008-06-02}}</ref> In March 1998 Universal put ''Hulk'' on [[Wikt:hiatus|hiatus]] due to its escalating $100 million budget and worries of Hensleigh directing his first film. $20 million was already spent on script development, computer animation, and prosthetics work. Hensleigh immediately went to rewrite the script in order to lower the budget.<ref>{{cite news|author = Chris Petrikin|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117468230|title = U has ''Hulk'' take a seat|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1998-03-02|accessdate = 2008-06-02}}</ref>
===Michael France=== Hensleigh found the rewriting process to be too difficult and dropped out, and felt he "wasted nine months in [[pre-production]]".<ref>{{cite news|author = Ken P|url = http://movies.ign.com/articles/496/496784p2.html|title = An Interview With Jonathan Hensleigh|publisher = [[IGN]]|date = 2004-03-05|accessdate = 2008-06-11}}</ref> It took another eight months for France to convince Universal and the producers to let him try to write a script for a third time. France claimed "Someone within the Universal hierarchy wasn't sure if this was a [[science fiction film|science fiction]] [[adventure film|adventure]], or a [[comedy film|comedy]], and I kept getting directions to write both. I think that at some point when I wasn't in the room, there may have been discussions about turning it into a [[Jim Carrey]] or [[Adam Sandler]] movie."<ref name=Hughes/> France was writing the script on fast track from July—September 1999. Filming for ''Hulk'' was to start in April 2000.<ref>{{cite news|author = Michael Fleming|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117503960|title = Marvel takes cue from its superheroes|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1999-07-13|accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = Michael Fleming|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117755342|title = Stewart goes boldly; renewed U fills its slate|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 1999-09-02|accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref>
France stated his vision of the film was different from the other drafts, which based Bruce Banner on his "amiable, [[nerd]]y genius" incarnation in the 1960s. France cited inspiration from the 1980s Hulk stories which introduced [[Brian Banner]], Bruce's abusive father who killed his mother. His script had Banner trying to create cells with regenerative capabilities in order to prove to himself that he is not like his father.<ref name=Hughes/> However, he has [[anger management]] issues before the Hulk is even created, which makes everything worse. The "Don't make me angry..." line from the [[The Incredible Hulk (1978 TV series)|TV series]] was made into dialogue that Banner's father would say before beating his son. Elements such as the "Gammasphere", Banner's tragic romance with Ross, and the [[Black Operation|black op]]s made it to the final film. France turned in his final drafts in late 1999-January 2000.<ref name=Hughes/>
===Ang Lee=== [[Michael Tolkin]] and [[David Hayter]] rewrote the script afterwards, despite positive response from the producers over France's script. Tolkin was brought in January 2000, while Hayter was brought in September of that year. Hayter's draft featured [[Leader (comics)|The Leader]], [[Zzzax]], and the [[Absorbing Man]] as the villains, who are depicted as colleagues of Banner and get caught in the same accident that creates the Hulk.<ref name=Hughes/><ref name="Hater"/><ref>{{cite news|author = Dayna Van Buskirk|title = Feature Article: The Lost ''Hulk'': David Hayter's Draft|publisher = [[UGO Networks]]|url = http://screenwriting.ugo.com/film/incrediblehulkbyhayter.php |accessdate=2010-04-27 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080602002713/http://screenwriting.ugo.com/film/incrediblehulkbyhayter.php |archivedate = 2008-06-02}}</ref> Director [[Ang Lee]] and his producing partner [[James Schamus]] became involved with the film in January 20, 2001.<ref>{{cite news|author = Cathy Dunkley|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117791724.html?categoryid=13&cs=1|title = From ''Tiger'' to U's ''Hulk'' for helmer|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 2001-01-12|accessdate = 2008-06-02}}</ref> Lee was dissatisfied with Hayter's script, and commissioned Schamus for a rewrite, merging Banner's father with the Absorbing Man.<ref name=Hughes/><ref>{{cite news|author = Andy Seiler|url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2001-04-13-ang-lee.htm#more|title = Ang Lee gets inside Hulk's head|work= [[USA Today]]|date = 2001-04-13|accessdate = 2008-06-11}}</ref> Lee cited influences from ''[[King Kong]]'', ''[[Frankenstein]]'', ''[[Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde|Jekyll and Hyde]]'', ''[[Beauty and the Beast]]'', ''[[Faust]]'', and [[Greek mythology]] for his interpretation of the story.<ref>{{cite news|author = Scott B|title = An Interview with Ang Lee|publisher = [[IGN]]|date = 2003-06-17|url = http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/424/424621p1.html|accessdate=2007-04-16}}</ref> Schamus said he had found the storyline that introduced Brian Banner, thus allowing Lee to write a drama that again explored father-son themes.<ref name="beast">{{cite news|author = Adam Smith|title = The Beast Within|pages = 66–77|work= [[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|date = 2003-05-30}}</ref>
Schamus was still rewriting the script in October 2001.<ref name=Rider>{{cite news|author = Michael Fleming|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117854264|title = Aussie has bulk for ''Hulk''|work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date = 2001-10-14|accessdate = 2008-06-02}}</ref> In early 2002, as filming was underway, Michael France read all the scripts for the [[Writers Guild of America]], to determine who would get final credit. France criticized Schamus and Hayter for claiming they were aiming to make Banner a deeper character, and was saddened they had denigrated his and Turman's work in interviews. Schamus elected to get solo credit. France felt, "James Schamus did a significant amount of work on the screenplay. For example, he brought in the Hulk dogs from the comics and he made the decision to use Banner's father as a real character in the present. But he used quite a lot of elements from John Turman's scripts and quite a lot from mine, and that's why we were credited."<ref name=Hughes/><ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url = http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2258|title = Countdown to 'Hulk': Screenwriter Michael France talks ''Hulk'', ''Punisher'' and Beyond|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-17|accessdate = 2008-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url =http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2206|title = Countdown to ''Hulk'': Producers Avi Arad and Gale Anne Hurd talk|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-05|accessdate = 2008-06-13}}</ref> France, Turman and Schamus received final credit. A theatrical release date for June 20, 2003 was announced in December 2001, with the film's title as ''The Hulk''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biz.yahoo.com:80/prnews/011217/lam095_1.html|title=Universal Pictures to Open 'The Hulk,' Directed by Ang Lee, on June 20, 2003|website=[[Business Wire]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway]]|date=December 17, 2001|accessdate=May 24, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020125092418/http://biz.yahoo.com:80/prnews/011217/lam095_1.html|archivedate=January 25, 2002}}</ref>
==Production== ===Filming=== Filming began on March 18, 2002 in [[Arizona]], and moved on April 19 to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. This included [[Advanced Light Source]], [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory|Lawrence Berkeley labs]], [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[Treasure Island (California)|Treasure Island military base]], and the sequoia forests of [[Porterville, California|Porterville]], before several weeks in the [[Utah]] and [[California]]n deserts. The penultimate battle scene between Hulk and his father used the real Pear Lake in Sequoia National Park as a backdrop. Filming then moved to the Universal backlot in [[Los Angeles]], using Stage 12 for the water tank scene, before finishing in the first week of August. Filming of ''Hulk'' constituted hiring 3,000 local workers, generating over $10 million into the local economy.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|title = Berkeley Workers Make Way For ''The Hulk''|date = 2002-04-16|url = http://www.mania.com/berkeley-workers-make-way-for-bithe-hulkib_article_88063.html|publisher = Comics2Film|accessdate=2010-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = David E.Williams|title = Temper, Temper,|date = July 2003|url = http://www.theasc.com/magazine/july03/cover/page2.html#|work= [[American Cinematographer]]|accessdate=2007-04-17}}</ref><ref name=Marv>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|title = Marvel CC: ''Hulk'' TV, ''Daredevil'' Trailer 2, ''Punisher'', More!|date = 2002-08-09|url = http://www.mania.com/marvel-cc-hulk-tv-daredevil-trailer-2-punisher-more_article_88811.html|publisher = Comics2Film|accessdate=2010-04-27}}</ref><ref name=Leung>{{cite news|author = Kevin Leung|url = http://www.mania.com/bihulkib-smashes-san-fran_article_88162.html|title = ''Hulk'' Smashes San Fran!|publisher = Comics2Film|date = 2002-04-26|accessdate = 2010-04-27}}</ref> [[Mychael Danna]], who previously collaborated with Lee on ''[[Ride with the Devil (film)|Ride with the Devil]]'' and ''[[The Ice Storm (film)|The Ice Storm]]'', was set to compose the [[film score]] before dropping out. [[Danny Elfman]] was then hired.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url = http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=1991|title = Comics2Film Wrap for April 3rd, 2003|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-04-03|accessdate = 2008-06-12}}</ref>
Eric Bana commented that the shoot was, "Ridiculously serious... a silent set, morbid in a lot of ways." Lee told him that he was shooting a Greek tragedy: he would be making a "whole other movie" about the Hulk at [[Industrial Light & Magic]]. An example of Lee's [[art film|art house]] approach to the film was taking Bana to watch a [[bare-knuckle boxing]] match.<ref name="beast"/> [[Visual effects supervisor]] [[Dennis Muren]] was on the set every day.<ref name=Hurd/> One of the many visual images in the film that presented an acting challenge for Bana was a [[split screen (film)|split screen]] technique employed by Lee to cinematically mimic the panels of a comic book page. This required many more takes of individual scenes than normal.<ref>{{cite news|author = Scott B|title = An Interview With Eric Bana|date = 2003-06-19|publisher = [[IGN]]|url = http://movies.ign.com/articles/425/425009p1.html|accessdate=2008-06-10}}</ref> [[Sound design]] was completed at [[Skywalker Sound]]. Muren and other ILM animators used previous technology from ''[[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)|Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets]]'' (for the [[Magical creatures (Harry Potter)#Dobby|Dobby]] character) to create the Hulk with [[computer-generated imagery]]. Other software used included [[PowerAnimator]], [[Softimage XSI]], and [[RenderMan Interface Specification]]. ILM started computer animation work in 2001, and completed in May 2003, just one month before the film's release.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url =http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2220|title = Countdown to ''Hulk'': Dennis Muren animates the big, green leading man|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-09|accessdate = 2008-06-17}}</ref> Lee provided some [[motion capture]] work in [[post-production]].<ref name=Chopper/>
==Music== ===Soundtrack=== {{Anchor|Music|Score|Soundtrack}} {{Infobox album | name = Hulk: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | artist = Danny Elfman | cover = | alt = | released = June 17, 2003 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack]] | length = 69:53 | label = [[Decca Records]] | producer = | chronology = ''Marvel Comics'' film series soundtrack | prev_title = [[X2 (film)#Music|X2: Original Motion Picture Score]] | prev_year = 2003 | next_title = [[The Punisher: The Album]] | next_year = 2004 }} The [[film score|musical score]] for ''Hulk'' was composed by [[Danny Elfman]], who scored ''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'' the previous year. Frequent Ang Lee collaborator, [[Mychael Danna]], was the original composer for the film. However, Danna's score was rejected by studio executives for its non-traditional approach, which featured Japanese taiko, African drumming, and Arabic singing.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wheeler|first1=Brad|title=Life of Pi composer Mychael Danna on making a soundtrack sing and a director happy|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/film-awards/life-of-pi-composer-mychael-danna-on-making-a-soundtrack-sing-and-a-director-happy/article8970089/|website=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=August 16, 2014|date=February 25, 2013}}</ref> Elfman was then approached by Universal's president of film music, Kathy Nelson. With 37 days to compose over two hours of music, Elfman agreed out of respect to Lee.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goldstein|first1=Patrick|title=Elfman masters a monster: Score one for 'The Hulk'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jun/24/entertainment/et-gold24|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|accessdate=August 16, 2014|date=June 24, 2003}}</ref> While instructing to retain much of the character of Danna's score, Lee pushed Elfman to write material that did not sound like his previous superhero scores.<ref>{{cite web|title=Filmtracks: Hulk |url=http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/hulk.html |website=[[Filmtracks.com]] |accessdate=August 16, 2014 |date=March 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030722044336/http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/hulk.html |archivedate=July 22, 2003 |df= }}</ref> "They did leave some of my music in the movie," said Danna, "so the Arabic singing and some of the drumming is mine. What happened is that they panicked, they brought in Danny and he heard what I've been doing and I guess he liked it."<ref>{{cite web|title=An Evening with Mychael Danna on the Phone|url=http://www.bsospirit.com/entrevistas/danna2_e.php|website=BSOSpirit|accessdate=August 16, 2014|page=2|date=March 20, 2004}}</ref>
A [[soundtrack album]] was released on June 17, 2003 by [[Decca Records]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Phares|first1=Heather|title=Hulk [Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/hulk-original-motion-picture-soundtrack-mw0000033896|website=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[All Media Network]]|accessdate=August 16, 2014}}</ref> It features the song "[[Set Me Free (Velvet Revolver song)|Set Me Free]]" by [[Velvet Revolver]], which is played during the film's end credits. ;Track listing {{Track listing | title1 = Main Titles | length1 = 4:36 | title2 = Prologue | length2 = 4:38 | title3 = Betty's Dream | length3 = 2:14 | title4 = Bruce's Memories | length4 = 2:45 | title5 = Captured | length5 = 3:41 | title6 = Dad's Visit | length6 = 2:15 | title7 = Hulk Out! | length7 = 4:00 | title8 = Father Knows Best | length8 = 3:34 | title9 = ...Making Me Angry | length9 = 4:02 | title10 = Gentle Giant | length10 = 1:02 | title11 = Hounds of Hell | length11 = 3:47 | title12 =The Truth Revealed | length12 = 4:19 | title13 = Hulk's Freedom | length13 = 2:36 | title14 = A Man Again | length14 = 7:48 | title15 = The Lake Battle | length15 = 4:32 | title16 = The Aftermath | length16 = 0:52 | title17 = The Phone Call | length17 = 1:34 | title18 = End Credit | length18 = 1:13 | title19 = Set Me Free | note19 = performed by [[Velvet Revolver]] | length19 = 4:09 }}
==Release== ===Marketing=== Universal Pictures spent $2.1 million to market the film in a 30-second [[television advertisement|television spot]] during [[Super Bowl XXXVII]] on January 26, 2003.<ref>{{cite news|author = Brian Linder|url = http://movies.ign.com/articles/383/383657p1.html|title = Super Bowl Shuffle|publisher = [[IGN]]|date = 2003-01-24|accessdate = 2008-06-11}}</ref> And a 70-second teaser trailer was attached to ''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'' on May 3, 2002. Just weeks before the film's release, a number of [[workprint]]s were leaked on the Internet. The visual and special effects were already being criticized, despite the fact that it was not the final editing cut of the film.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Rob Worley]]|url =http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=2231|title = ''Criminal Macabre'', ''Transformers'', ''Hulk'' and ''Spider-Man'': Comics2Film wrap for June 11, 2003|publisher = [[Comic Book Resources]]|date = 2003-06-11|accessdate = 2008-06-14}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''Hulk'' was released on VHS and DVD on October 28, 2003.<ref>{{cite news|author = Jennifer Netherby| url =http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-107255047.html|format=Fee required|title = Jolly green giant|work= Video Business |publisher=[[HighBeam Research]]|date = 2003-09-01|accessdate = 2010-04-27}}</ref> The film earned $61.2 million in DVD sales during 2003.<ref name="leesmovieinfo.net">{{cite web| title = DVD Sales Chart 2003|publisher = Lee's Movie Info|date = 2005-04-19|url =http://www.leesmovieinfo.net/Video-Sales.php?type=3&week_id=144&limit=54| accessdate=2010-04-27}}</ref> ''Hulk'' was released on HD DVD format on December 12, 2006 and it was later released on Blu-ray on September 16, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Hulk-Blu-ray-Review/1140/|title=Hulk Blu-ray Review|last=Liebman|first=Martin |date=September 30, 2008|publisher=Blu-ray.com|accessdate=2009-09-28}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Critical response=== ''Hulk'' received mixed-to-positive reviews. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] calculated a 62% approval rating out of 232 reviews. The website's critical consensus reads, "While Ang Lee's ambitious film earns marks for style and an attempt at dramatic depth, there's ultimately too much talking and not enough smashing."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hulk/|title = Hulk (2003)|publisher = [[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate = 2010-04-27}}</ref> By comparison [[Metacritic]] collected an average score of 54 based on 40 reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.metacritic.com/movie/hulk| title = Hulk (2003): Reviews|publisher = [[Metacritic]]|accessdate = 2010-04-27}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] gave a positive review, explaining, "[[Ang Lee]] is trying to actually deal with the issues in the story of the Hulk, instead of simply cutting to brainless [[visual effects]]." Ebert also liked how the Hulk's movements resembled [[King Kong]].<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Roger Ebert]]|url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20030620/REVIEWS/306200304/1023|title = Hulk|work= [[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date = 2003-06-20|accessdate = 2008-06-04}}</ref> Although [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' felt ''Hulk'' should have been shorter, he heavily praised the action sequences, especially the [[climax (narrative)|climax]] and [[cliffhanger]].<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Peter Travers]]|url = https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/the-hulk-20030620|title = Hulk|work= [[Rolling Stone]]|date = 2003-06-20|accessdate = 2011-03-10}}</ref> [[Paul Clinton]] of ''[[CNN]]'' believed the cast gave strong performances, but in an otherwise positive review, heavily criticized the [[computer-generated imagery]], calling the Hulk "a ticked-off version of [[Shrek (character)|Shrek]]".<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Paul Clinton]]|url = http://www.cnn.com/2003/SHOWBIZ/Movies/06/19/sprj.cas03.review.hulk/index.html|title = ''Hulk'' not quite all there|publisher = [[CNN]]|date = 2003-06-20|accessdate = 2011-03-10}}</ref>
Conversely, [[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' considered "the film is more thoughtful and pleasing to the eye than any blockbuster in recent memory, but its epic length comes without an epic reward."<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Mick LaSalle]]|url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/10/31/DD153299.DTL|title = ''Hulk'' is a smash-'em-up blockbuster|work= [[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date = 2003-10-31|accessdate = 2008-06-05}}</ref> [[Ty Burr]] of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' felt "[[Jennifer Connelly]] reprises her stand-by-your-messed-up-scientist turn from ''[[A Beautiful Mind (film)|A Beautiful Mind]]''."<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Ty Burr]]|url = http://www.boston.com/movies/display?display=movie&id=1842|title = This not-so-incredible ''Hulk'' takes simple joys to serious extremes|publisher = [[The Boston Globe]]|date = 2003-06-29|accessdate = 2008-06-05}}</ref> Lisa Schwarzbaum of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' stated, "a big-budget comic-book adaptation has rarely felt so humorless and intellectually defensive about its own pulpy roots."<ref>{{cite news|author = Lisa Schwarzbaum|url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,458306~1~0~hulk,00.html|title = The Hulk (2003)|work= [[Entertainment Weekly]]|date = 2003-06-20|accessdate = 2008-06-06}}</ref>
In later years, ''Hulk'' received retrospective praise from critics for its artistic difference from other superhero films. In 2012, [[Matt Zoller Seitz]] cited the film as one of the few big budget superhero films that "really departed from formula, in terms of subject matter or tone", writing that the film is "pretty bizarre... in its old-school Freudian psychology, but interesting for that reason".<ref>{{cite web|author1=[[Matt Zoller Seitz|Seitz, Matt Zoller]]|author2=Abrams, Simon|title=TRAILER WATCH – Marvel’s THE AVENGERS: Just Another Superhero Movie?|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2012/03/trailer-watch-marvels-the-avengers-just-another-superhero-movie-132289/|website=[[IndieWire]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation|Penske Business Media, LLC]]|accessdate=13 November 2018|date=6 March 2012}}</ref> In Scout Tafoya's 2016 video essay on another film directed by Ang Lee, ''[[Ride with the Devil (film)|Ride with the Devil]]'', he mentioned ''Hulk'' as "Lee's ill-fated but quietly soulful and deeply sad adaptation of ''The Incredible Hulk'' comics".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tafoya|first1=Scout|title=The Unloved - Ride with the Devil|url=https://vimeo.com/181056445|website=[[Vimeo]]|publisher=Vimeo, Inc.|accessdate=13 November 2018|date=1 September 2016}}</ref> In 2018, Peter Sobczynski of [[RogerEbert.com]] wrote that the film is "a genuinely great example of cinematic pop art that deserves a reappraisal".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sobczynski|first1=Peter|title=Stan Lee: 1922-2018|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/balder-and-dash/stan-lee-1922-2018|website=[[Roger Ebert]]|publisher=Ebert Digital LLC|accessdate=13 November 2018|date=12 November 2018}}</ref>
===Box office=== ''Hulk'' was released on June 20, 2003, earning $62.1 million in its opening weekend, which made it the 16th highest ever opener at the time. With a second weekend drop of 70%, it was the first opener above $20 million to drop over 65%.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/weekends/drops.htm| title=Biggest Second Weekend Drops at the Box Office |work= [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=2007-03-13}}</ref> The film went on to gross $132,177,234 in North America on an estimated budget of $137,000,000, and made $113,183,246 in foreign countries, coming to a worldwide total of $245,360,480.<ref name=mojo>{{cite web|url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hulk.htm|title = Hulk (2003)|publisher = [[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate = 2008-06-02}}</ref> With a final North American gross of $132.2 million it became the largest opener not to earn $150 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/weekends/|title=Biggest Opening Weekends at the Box Office|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2007-03-13}}</ref>
===Accolades=== Connelly and [[Danny Elfman]] received nominations at the [[30th Saturn Awards]] with [[Saturn Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] and [[Saturn Award for Best Music|Best Music]]. The film was nominated for [[Saturn Award for Best Science Fiction Film|Best Science Fiction Film]] but lost out to another film based on Marvel characters, ''[[X2 (film)|X2]]''. [[Dennis Muren]], [[Michael Lantieri]] and the [[special effects]] crew were nominated for [[Saturn Award for Best Special Effects|Best Special Effects]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.saturnawards.org/san30.html|title = The 30th Annual Saturn Awards Nominations|publisher = [[Saturn Award]]s|accessdate = 2010-04-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041009185400/http://www.saturnawards.org/san30.html |archivedate=2004-10-09}}</ref>
==Reboot== {{Main|The Incredible Hulk (film)}} After the mixed reception of ''Hulk'', [[Marvel Studios]] reacquired the film rights to the character, and writer [[Zak Penn]] began work on a sequel titled ''The Incredible Hulk''. However, [[Edward Norton]] rewrote Penn's script after he signed on to star, retelling the origin story in flashbacks and revelations, to help in establishing the film as a [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]]; director [[Louis Leterrier]] agreed with this approach.<ref name=muscle>{{cite news| title = Norton's Double Duty on Hulk|publisher = SuperheroHype.com| date = 2007-08-15|url = http://www.superherohype.com/news/topnews.php?id=6209|accessdate=2007-09-06}}</ref> Leterrier acknowledged that the only remaining similarity between the two films was Bruce hiding in [[South America]].<ref name=nycc>{{cite news| title = . "Exclusive: Leterrier [sic] , Feige and Hurd on Hulk's Return"|publisher = SuperheroHype.com| date = 2008-04-21|url = http://www.superherohype.com/news/topnews.php?id=6209|accessdate=2013-02-09}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Hulk (video game)|''Hulk'' (video game)]] {{Portalbar|Film in the United States|Superhero fiction|2000s}}
