revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Muscovite Russia to [[:Category:Tsardom of Russia]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 March 26]].
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=November 2006}} '''Pevchy dyak''' ({{Lang-ru|певчий дьяк}}) is a historical name of [[singer]]'s occupation in [[Russia]]. They were singers at [[tsar]]'s court and in [[church choir]]s of higher church hierarchs: [[patriarch]], [[metropolitan (Orthodox Church)|metropolitan]], [[archiereus]] ([[bishop]] of the [[Orthodox Church]]).
The title (in both senses) was abolished by [[Peter the Great]] in 1720s during his massive reforms of the Russian state.
==See also== *[[Dyachok]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pevchy Dyak}} [[Category:Obsolete occupations]] [[Category:Singing]] [[Category:Tsardom of Russia]] [[Category:Russian Empire]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 4 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
[[File:Judging of Best Pig in Show at Stoneleigh Park, Warwickshire.jpg|thumb|Pig judging in Britain]] '''Pig shows''' are an event where [[pigs]] are evaluated for their quality. They are evaluated on a multitude of things which include composition (muscle vs. fat), capaciousness, and skeletal integrity along with general appearance and conformation to their respective breed. Other names for a pig show include '''swine show''' and '''hog show'''. A pig show is frequently part of a larger [[agricultural show]].
==History== Pig shows began on farms where the owner and other pig farmers would gather to decide which pig had the best qualities for [[Selective breeding|breeding]]. These would not be named pig shows, but ultimately they were making a decision on which animals to retain to breed. Eventually, breeders would meet at a specified location and bring an outside person to evaluate their pigs, and to order them in a ranking. These were the first shows.
A show is typically divided up into classes so that the judge can study fewer pigs at a time. Typically these classes are broken down to the breed of pig, weight, or age. There are division or breed champions and reserve champions. Then ultimately, an over-all grand champion will be chosen. <ref>Wendt, K.</ref>
==Swine judging== Swine judging is the process of selectively ordering swine or [[domestic pig]]s in order to determine the best pig. For market hogs, traits are ranked in order of their importance: Degree of muscling, growth, capacity or volume, degree of leanness, structure and soundness.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ca.uky.edu/agripedia/agmania/livestock/Hogs/hogmark.asp |title = Ranking of Traits for Market Hogs |publisher = University of Kentucky, College of Agriculture |accessdate = 2011-08-19 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120324225503/http://www.ca.uky.edu/agripedia/agmania/livestock/Hogs/hogmark.asp |archivedate = 2012-03-24 |df = }}</ref> For breeding gilts, the traits by order of importance are: Structure and soundness, Growth, Underline quality, Capacity or volume, Degree of muscling, Degree of leanness.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ca.uky.edu/agripedia/agmania/livestock/Hogs/hogmate.asp |title = Ranking of Traits for Maternal Line Breeding Gilts |publisher = University of Kentucky, College of Agriculture |accessdate = 2011-08-19 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120324225508/http://www.ca.uky.edu/agripedia/agmania/livestock/Hogs/hogmate.asp |archivedate = 2012-03-24 |df = }}</ref>
A judge will have different priorities and rank importance of certain traits differently than other judges. Judges are selected because they are typically influential breeders within the show pig industry.
==Pig shows by country==
===Major Pig shows in the United States=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name of Pig Show ! Location |- | North American International Livestock Exposition |Louisville, Kentucky |- | World Pork Expo and Junior Event | [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]], [[Iowa]] |- | Summer Type Conference and National Junior Summer Spectacular | [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]] |- |Southeast Type Conference |Perry, Georgia |- | Summer Type Conference (CPS) | [[Socorro, New Mexico|Springfield, Illinois]] |- | Oklahoma Youth Expo | [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]] |- | Southwest Type Conference | [[Belton, Texas|Belton]], Texas |- | Southwest Hampshire Type Conference | [[Sweetwater, Texas|Sweetwater]], [[Texas]] |- |National Barrow Show |Austin, Minnesota |} Show pig breeds in the United States {| class="wikitable" |Berkshire |- |Chester White |- |Duroc |- |Hampshire |- |Hereford |- |Landrace |- |Poland China |- |Spot |- |Tamworth |- |Yorkshire |- |Cross Bred |}
=== Pig shows in People's Republic of China === In [[People's Republic of China|China]], the first pig show was the Guangdong Breeding Pigs Auction which began January 18, 1996.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | script-title=zh:拍卖与养猪生产发展的融合——第7届湖北种猪拍卖展销暨学术交流会 | date= | publisher=中国种猪信息网 | url =http://www.teacup-pigs.info/chinese-pig-auction.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-19 | language = zh }}</ref> Most pig shows in china are pig-breeding auctions. More than 10 provinces have in the past hosted these pig-breeding auctions, but only two provinces ([[Guangdong Province]] and [[Hubei Province]]) still host it.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | script-title=zh:广东省种猪拍卖会举行 长白种猪2万元夺魁 | date= | publisher=广东农业信息网 | url =http://www.agri.gov.cn/dfxxlb/gdxxlb/t20071220_940931.htm | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2008-09-02 | language = zh }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Name of Pig Show ! Location ! Date |- | Guangdong Pig Industry Expo(Chinese: 广东省养猪产业博览会) | [[Guangzhou]], [[Guangdong Province]] | June 16 - June 18 and December 16 - December 18, twice per year |- | Hubei Breeding Pigs Auction(Chinese: 湖北种猪测定拍卖会) | [[Wuhan]], [[Hubei Province]] | October 17 - October 18, once per year |}
===Pig Show in Australia=== In [[Australia]], '''The Sydney Royal Easter Show Competition''' is held annually. The [[Sydney Royal Easter Show]] is one of the largest and most prestigious Pig Shows in [[Australia]]. It is held in [[Sydney]], at the Paddington Pavilion. Pigs were exhibited at the first Sydney Royal Easter Show in 1858 and the pig competition has been held at nearly every show since. Exhibitors that compete at the Sydney Royal Pig Show are often from small family-based Stud farms.<ref>Sydney Royal Pig Show {{cite web |url=http://www.sydneyroyal.com.au/Pig.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219174524/http://www.sydneyroyal.com.au/Pig.htm |archivedate=2011-02-19 |df= }}</ref>
Pig breeds exhibited include: [[Berkshire (pig)]], [[Duroc (pig)]], [[Hampshire (pig)]], [[American Landrace]], [[Large White pig]], [[Tamworth pig]] [[Wessex Saddleback]] pig.
==See also== *[[Swine judging]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.nationalswine.com/ National Swine Registry] *[http://www.antwifarms.com/swinegenetic.shtml Swine Genetics Publications] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070203015135/http://www.ces.purdue.edu/pork/ Purdue Pork Page] *[http://www.babcockgenetics.com Babcock Genetics Inc.] *[http://www.babcockgenetics.com Babcock Genetics Inc.] *[http://www.teacup-pigs.info/chinese-pig-auction.html Chinese Pig Show] {{Pigs}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox video game |image=Rabbids Big Bang.jpg |caption= |developer=[[Ubisoft Milan]]
[[Ubisoft Paris]] |publisher=[[Ubisoft]] |series=''[[Raving Rabbids]]'' |engine= |platforms=[[iOS (Apple)|iOS]]
[[Android (operating system)|Android]] |released={{Video game release|WW|October 17, 2013 {{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/10/11/rabbids-big-bang-lands-on-ios-on-october-17/|title=Rabbids Big Bang lands on iOS on October 17|publisher=AOL|work=Engadget|first=Mike|last=Wehner|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2016}}}} |genre=[[Puzzle video game|Puzzle]], [[Party game#Party video games|Party]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single player]] }} '''''Rabbids Big Bang''''' is a [[video game]] which was developed by [[Ubisoft Milan]] in collaboration with [[Ubisoft Paris]] and published by [[Ubisoft]] on October 17, 2013 in Europe, North America and Japan for [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. This is a [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] game of the ''[[Raving Rabbids]]'' games franchise.{{cite web|url=http://www.ubi.com/US/Games/Info.aspx?pId=11981|title=Ubisoft - Rabbids Big Bang|publisher=Ubi.com|accessdate=October 5, 2014}} ==Gameplay== The game features 150 levels. In this game, players control the Rabbids along with their [[jetpack]]s to fling them across space, avoiding obstacles such as cows and the gravitational forces of other planets. Players are able to customize both their Rabbid and its jetpack.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/09/10/rayman-fiesta-run-rabbids-big-bang-coming-to-mobile|title=Rayman Fiesta Run, Rabbids Big Bang Coming to Mobile|work=IGN|first=Andrew|last=Goldfarb|date=September 10, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2016}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = (iOS) 62/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/rabbids-big-bang|title=Rabbid's Big Bang|work=Metacritic|accessdate=February 1, 2016}} | rev1 = [[TouchArcade]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://toucharcade.com/2013/10/18/rabbids-big-bang-review/|title=Rabbids Big Bang Review - TouchArcade|work=TouchArcade|first=Shaun|last=Musgrave|date=October 18, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2016}} | rev2 = [[Pocket Gamer]] | rev2Score = 4/10{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/iPad/Rabbids+Big+Bang/review.asp?c=54693|title=Rabbids Big Bang|work=Pocket Gamer|first=Harry|last=Slater|date=October 25, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2016}} | rev3 = [[GameZebo]] | rev3Score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezebo.com/2013/10/22/rabbids-big-bang-review/|title=Rabbids Big Bang Review|work=Gamezebo|first=Neilie|last=Johnson|date=October 22, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2016}} }} ''Rabbids Big Bang'' received mixed or average reviews. Touch Arcade called it predictable and lacking in humor. Pocket Gamer complained about the sense of physics and a lack of personality, calling the game frustrating and forgettable. GameZebo found the game humorous but felt the gameplay was shallow and ultimately best suited for short play sessions. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Raving Rabbids series}} [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Party video games]] [[Category:Raving Rabbids]] [[Category:Ubisoft games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Italy]] {{Puzzle-videogame-stub}}

{{Infobox music festival | name =Raindance | image = | caption = | location =[[United Kingdom]] | years_active =1989–present | founders =Raindance | dates = | genre = [[Electronic dance music]] | attendance = | capacity = | website = }} '''Raindance''' are British [[rave]] event organisers. They were one of the best known rave names on the Rave scene in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
The first event was held at a circus tent on 16 September 1989 at Jenkins Lane, [[Beckton]] in east [[London]]. This was Britain's first legal all night rave.<ref>[http://muckfm.com/raindance_303 Raindance rave festivals - Muck FM]</ref><ref>[http://www.raveflyers.co.uk/gallery/images_temp/raindance_undercover_16sep89.jpg Flyer for the very first Raindance event]</ref>
DJ's such as [[Carl Cox]], [[Dave Angel]], [[LTJ Bukem]], [[Mr C]], [[DJ Rap]], [[John Digweed]], [[Kevin Saunderson|Kevin "Reece" Saunderson]], [[Slipmatt]], [[Fabio (DJ)|Fabio]] and [[Grooverider]] started out at Raindance. Live acts such as Shades of Rhythm, [[N-Joi]] and [[The Prodigy]] have all played at Raindance. [[File:Raindance MA2.jpg|thumb|right|MA-2 bomber jacket with the Raindance logo]] From 1989 to 1993, Raindance went on to hold large-scale events across [[Essex]], [[Cambridgeshire]], [[Leicestershire]],<ref>[http://scrapbook.sean.at/?p=12 Raindance@ 7am Melton (Mowbray) Airfield] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070810022012/http://scrapbook.sean.at/?p=12 |date=2007-08-10 }}</ref> [[Oxfordshire]], [[Somerset]] and even Spain. The venues Raindance used held up to 10,000 ravers. DJ Slipmatt's brother, Paul Nelson, was one of the original promoters. The original idea to hold a rave came from Slipmatt himself.<ref>[http://www.kineticpromotions.org/bin/content/dj_slipmatt.html Kinetic Promotions - DJ Slipmatt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518120403/http://www.kineticpromotions.org/bin/content/dj_slipmatt.html |date=2011-05-18 }}</ref>
But by 1993 with pressure from the authorities ([[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]]) and the rave music scene splintering into different dance genres, Raindance took a break from holding mass events. Between 1993 and 1998 there were one-off events, then the promoters returned hosting regular indoor events in clubs around North and East London.
In 1999 Raindance started hosting raves at The Drome, an unused car park underneath [[London Bridge railway station]]. They would get regular attendances of over 2,000 people at this venue. In 2002, The Drome was renovated and [[SEOne|seOne]] was born. Over the next 8 years SeOne would be Raindance's home and with a 3,000 capacity with 7 different arenas (Jenkins Lane 89-90, Old Skool 91-93, Jungle/Drum & Bass 93-10, Hardcore 95-10, Hard House, Breakbeat, House & Trance). Raindance continues to put parties on all over the UK.
==See also== {{Portal|Electronic music}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Raindance (rave)}} *[http://www.fantazia.org.uk/Scene/orgs/raindance.htm Raindance - Old Skool/Rave - Fantazia.org.uk] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fMCEefry7cE&feature=related Raindance 1990 Part 7 Old Skool Rave - YouTube] *[http://www.tapesgalore.co.uk/flyers/raindance_07-02-1992.htm Flyer for event at Wisbech - February 7 1992] {{Electronic music festival}}
[[Category:Music festivals established in 1989]] [[Category:Dance organizations]] [[Category:Rave culture in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Rave]] [[Category:Electronic music festivals in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Electronic music event management companies]]

revision.comment: /* Startup develops a strategy */ reword for clarity
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = SmartStudy | logo = File:SmartStudy logo.png | image = | image_caption = | type = [[Educational entertainment]] | slogan = | foundation = {{start date and age|2010|06}} | location = 5th Floor, 94 Myeongdal-ro, [[Seocho-dong]], [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | key_people = [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] Kim Min-seok
[[Chief financial officer|CFO]] Lee Ryan Seung-kyu
[[Vice president|VP]] Park Hyun-woo | industry = [[Animation#production|Animation production]] | products = | revenue = | revenue_year = | net_income = | net_income_year = | assets = | assets_year = | equity = | equity_year = | num_employees = 160 | homepage = {{URL|https://www.smartstudy.co.kr/en/}} }} ''SmartStudy''' ({{lang-ko|스마트스터디}}), is a South Korean [[educational entertainment]] company established in 2010, a [[subsidiary]] of Samsung Publishing Co Ltd. It develops [[mobile app]]lications for children and owns [[intellectual property]] rights for its popular animated characters, including [[Pinkfong]] and Baby Shark, whose mobile app was reported in November, 2018 to have been downloaded by 150 million people in 112 countries. In 2016, the company released their first [[Video game|game]], "Monster Super League".{{cite web|last=Song|first=Seung-hyun|title=SmartStudy gears up for IPO in 2020|url=http://www.theinvestor.co.kr/view.php?ud=20181101000668|date=November 1, 2018|work=[[The Korea Herald]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}}{{cite web|title=Company Info Samsung Publishing Co. Ltd|url=https://quotes.wsj.com/KR/068290/company-people|date=November 27, 2018 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} ==History== ===Company formation=== ====Parent company and founders==== SmartStudy was founded in June, 2010,{{cite web|last=Shin|first=Myung-jin|title= [Made In Korea] Education Contents Firm Targeting Children, 'SmartStudy'|url=http://us.aving.net/news/view.php?articleId=1374030&mn_name=|date=November 21, 2018|work=AVING Global Network|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} by three former game developers, [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] Kim Min-seok, [[Chief financial officer|CFO]] Lee Ryan Seung-kyu and [[Vice president|VP]] Park Hyun-woo.{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Ho-jeong|title=How SmartStudy’s pink fox became a global hit|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3035971|date=July 18, 2017|work=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} Kim, who was around thirty-years-old at the time, was a publisher and the oldest son at his family's business, Samsung Publishing Company Ltd., SmartSudy's [[parent company]], with his father, CEO Kim Jin-yong, and his grandfather, the company's founder, Kim Bong-kyu.{{cite web|title=김민석 삼성출판사 N그룹장 "인기 앱이 종이책 매출 늘려.. 전자책-종이책 윈윈 가능해"|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/%EA%B9%80%EB%AF%BC%EC%84%9D-%EC%82%BC%EC%84%B1%EC%B6%9C%ED%8C%90%EC%82%AC-n%EA%B7%B8%EB%A3%B9%EC%9E%A5-%EC%9D%B8%EA%B8%B0-%EC%95%B1%EC%9D%B4-%EC%A2%85%EC%9D%B4%EC%B1%85-%EB%A7%A4%EC%B6%9C-%EB%8A%98%EB%A0%A4-090016259.html|date=March 7, 2012|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|language=Korean|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} The company, established on July 3, 2002, has no relation to the [[Samsung|Samsung Group]],{{cite web|last=Huang|first=Eustance|title=A Korean company's stock surged more than 76% after a children's song about sharks cracked UK charts|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/06/baby-shark-samsung-publishing-stock-soars-on-success-of-viral-song.html|date=September 6, 2018|work=[[CNBC]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} and mainly published books for children and magazines for computer users, with another division operating food courts in highway service areas and a subsidiary operation that marketed stationery products.{{cite web|title=About Samsung Publishing Co Ltd|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/068290:KS|date=November 27, 2018|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} Kim joined the company, in preparation as successor, in 2008, and, while there, he helped launch a self-directed program "Samsung English", and worked on content [[digitization]] and app development. He studied to be an [[Information professional|information specialist]] at [[Yonsei University]] and worked at the game company [[Nexon]] while in college. After graduation, he was a developer and project manager at [[Hangame]] and also, worked at [[NHN Entertainment Corporation|NHN]]. With Samsung Publishing as it's first investor, the media [[startup company]]{{cite web|last=Ramirez|first=Elaine|title=How This 'Baby Shark' Video Went Insanely Viral In Indonesia|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/elaineramirez/2017/09/01/smartstudy-pinkfong-baby-shark-video-indonesia/#1de845873e19|date=September 1, 2017|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} SmartStudy was formed by Kim, his close friend Park, who also worked at NHN, and Lee, who he met at Nexon. Lee had begun his career as an [[online community]] developer at Freechal. ====Startup develops a strategy==== While brainstorming ideas for the company, the thought of making video games was quickly dropped, because, as Lee said, “At that point, we were all tired of making games". The final choices were education and medicine, but as they had no expertise in medicine, they focused on education. With more ideas from Samsung Publishing, they decided to focus on the children's education market by making and uploading four music videos for Samsung Publishing's children's songs on their apps. The international response was good. “It was then that we realized that instead of making what we want, we should create content based on what the market wants,” Lee said. Discussing what market they would focus on, Kim said reaching out to global customers was more viable, as potential customers were limited in South Korea, where the birthrate per year was around 400,000.{{cite web|last=Kim|first=Young-joo|title=통통 튀는 핑크퐁, 뽀로로가 샘내겠네요|url=https://news.joins.com/article/21565204|date=May 12, 2017|work=[[JoongAng Ilbo]]|language=Korean|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} They further planned to target [[pre-kindergarten]] or 2-year-old to [[kindergarten]], looking to open offices in China and the U.S. to make local content geared for each of those markets. According to Lee, the U.S. users favored "interactive, actionable content such as writing letters on the tablet or taking pictures with the character", while Asian users preferred "one-way streaming video content".{{cite web|last=Yoo|first=Eva|title=SmartStudy: Kindergarten Education On IoT|url=https://technode.com/2015/07/01/smartstudy-kindergarten-education-iot/|date=July 1, 2015|work=TechNode|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} Based on results in South Korea and China, they focused on creating content in English and Spanish for the U.S. market,{{cite web|last=Kim|first=Ji-yeon|title=Local IT startups attracts millions of investment from Chinese capital|url=https://www.arirang.com/News/News_Print.asp?type=news&nseq=191693|date=May 27, 2016|work=[[ArirangTV]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} and started producing videos with its characters in several languages, including English, Chinese, Spanish and Russian; and operating its own mobile app providing content directly to viewers. Many of the creators at the company were from children's book publishing and many of the apps were based on [[chant]] melodies to attract children's attention.{{cite web|last=Yoo|first=Eva|title=South Korea’s First-Gen Unicorn Game Developers Are Now Gamifying Education|url=https://technode.com/2016/02/24/korean-game-developer-parents-are-gamifying-child-education/|date=February 24, 2016|work=TechNode|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} They also added [[Video on demand|mobile VOD]], comics, and finally, games.{{cite web|title=Company Overview of SMARTSTUDY Co., Ltd|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=245212275|date=November 27, 2018|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} As the company grew, they continued their debate on games and entertainment versus education. "Education combined with entertainment, [[Educational entertainment|edutainment]], is hard to achieve. If it’s too much focused on games, it has less educational value, and if it’s too much focused on education, it will need sugar-coating with game features", Lee said. Consequently, they returned to their forte in September, 2016, when they released a mobile game called “Monster Super League”. Kim said he understood the importance of child education, but thought about the expertise of team members who were prior game developers at Nexon or [[NCSoft]], and who were also fathers. They realized their market with international growth through [[Google]] and [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] [[app store]]s and expanded to [[IPTV]] in late 2013. They felt their willingness to understand subtle cultural differences instead of just enhancing language aspects benefited them. An example they provided was utilizing country differences in the sounds a police car siren makes, to localize their products for children. In particular, for Chinese marketing, they created new work using old [[Chinese folklore|Chinese fables]] and texts that Chinese children would know from kindergarten, and uploading on native platforms like [[Youku]], [[iQiyi]] and [[Tencent Video]] in China, where [[YouTube]] is banned. ====Work atmosphere and locations==== Journalist Kwon Oh-seong of [[The Hankyoreh]] visited the company for interviews in April, 2015 and described a unique organizational culture that emphasized autonomous work. His visit coincided with a customary monthly birthday rooftop celebration, presently the one for 34-year-old CEO Kim. The employees, with an average age of thirty, called each other by nicknames like "Radio", and "Patriarch" for Kim, and detailed a flexible work atmosphere, with periods of self-imposed hard work, along with [[chimaek]] breaks and unlimited vacation rewards. Kim said the structure is based on the teachings of his father, who allowed him freedom to grow and create on his own.{{cite web|last=Kwon|first=Oh-seong|title=휴가 무제한인 회사…그래도 잘 나가요|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/economy/economy_general/686640.html|date=April 13, 2015|work=[[The Hankyoreh]]|language=Korean|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} By 2017, the company had branches in [[Los Angeles]] and [[Shanghai]]. In 2017, CEO Bin Jeong, of Pinkfong's U.S. branch, which opened in 2016 with a couple of employees, said SmartStudy had about 150 employees,{{cite web|title=Pinkfong Q&A|url=https://thesavvyscreener.com/2017/08/14/pinkfong-qa/|date=August 14, 2017|work=The Savvy Screeener|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} and writing about women in [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] jobs, she said about 60 percent were women.{{cite web|last=Bin|first=Jeong|title=What Women Want: How to Encourage Female Talent to Pursue STEM Jobs|url=http://www.edtechroundup.org/editorials--press/guest-post-what-women-want-how-to-encourage-female-talent-to-pursue-stem-jobs|date=August 3, 2017|work=The Ed Tech Roundup|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} ===Success with Pinkfong and "Baby Shark"=== In August 2015, their big breakthrough occurred on YouTube with their popular character and [[brand]] Pinkfong, a [[magenta]]-colored animated fox, which was used in a "[[Baby Shark#Pinkfong versions|Baby Shark]]" song and dance video. It was launched in late 2015, and started going viral on YouTube in 2016, becoming the company's most popular series with 800 million views by September 2018. By 2018, the company reported 150 million people in 112 countries had downloaded its app. ==Finance and sales== By 2014, the parent company, Samsung Publishing, was seeing an increased net profit from its new subsidiary SmartStudy,{{cite web|last=Ko|first=Jong-min|title=[종목이슈] 삼성출판사, 계열사 이익 급증…매출 '사상 최대'|url=http://www.newspim.com/news/view/20150319000354|date=March 19, 2014|work=NewsPim|language=Korean|accessdate=November 27, 2018}} and in 2017, Samsung Publishing sales were approximately $160 million. In 2015, SmartStudy's sales were 9.5 billion won (about US$8.5 million). In 2016, SmartStudy's sales increased 80 percent, due to revenue from YouTube and apps sales, to 17.5 billion [[South Korean won|won]] (about US$15.5 million), with overseas sales accounting for 65 percent. In 2017, SmartStudy sales were 27.2 billion won (about US$24,127,000) with an operating profit of 1.9 billion won (about US$1,685,000). In September 2018, Samsung Publishing's stocks "soared" by more than 76 percent after Pinkfong's "Baby Shark" song charted on the [[UK Singles Chart|UK Top 40]] at number 37. In November 2018, industry sources were predicting that SmartStudy was preparing to go [[Initial public offering|public]] in 2020, with CEO Kim the biggest shareholder with 23.1 percent stake and Samsung Publishing which owns 20.8 percent. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.smartstudy.co.kr/en/ Official website] [[Category:Entertainment companies of South Korea]] [[Category:Media companies of South Korea]]
